G.L. c. 186, \u00a7 14.proposition: This action arises under the landlord‑tenant laws of the Commonwealth of Massachusetts, including but not limited to G.L. c. 186, § 14, and the common law and public policy of Massachusetts relating to the covenant of quiet enjoyment.

G.L. c. 223, \u00a7\u00a7 1 et seq..proposition: Venue is proper in the Springfield District Court pursuant to G.L. c. 223, §§ 1 et seq., because the Premises are located in Springfield, Hampden County, Massachusetts, and the events giving rise to this action occurred within this Court’s territorial jurisdiction.

G.L. c. 111, \u00a7 127A.proposition: Massachusetts law requires landlords to maintain rental premises in compliance with the State Sanitary Code, including the provision of adequate and safe electrical service.

105 C.M.R. 410.000 et seq. (Minimum Stan.raw_text: 105 C.M.R. 410.000 et seq. (Minimum Standards of Fitness for Human Habitation)
105 C.M.R. 410.000 et seq. (Minimum Stan.proposition: Massachusetts law requires landlords to maintain rental premises in compliance with the State Sanitary Code, including the provision of adequate and safe electrical service.

105 C.M.R. 410.351, 410.354 (requiring s.raw_text: 105 C.M.R. 410.351, 410.354 (requiring safe and adequate electrical and lighting facilities)
105 C.M.R. 410.351, 410.354 (requiring s.proposition: The duty to provide and maintain safe and functional electrical service is part of the landlord’s obligation to comply with the State Sanitary Code and to preserve the tenant’s right to habitable and usable premises.

G.L. c. 239, \u00a7 8A.proposition: Plaintiff also has remedies under related landlord‑tenant doctrines, including the warranty of habitability (see Boston Hous. Auth. v. Hemingway, 363 Mass. 184 (1973)) and G.L. c. 239, § 8A, but in this action she asserts only a claim for breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment under G.L. c. 186, § 14.

Blackett v. Olanoff, 371 Mass. 714 (1977.proposition: Under Massachusetts law, every residential lease contains an implied covenant of quiet enjoyment, guaranteeing the tenant’s right to undisturbed use and enjoyment of the leased premises.
Blackett v. Olanoff, 371 Mass. 714 (1977.support_reasoning: The opinion squarely treats quiet enjoyment as an implied covenant/warranty in every residential lease and applies it to bar the landlords’ rent claims. The court repeatedly refers to the “tenants’ implied warranty of quiet enjoyment” and analyzes whether the landlords’ conduct breached that implied covenant by substantially depriving tenants of the use and enjoyment of their apartments. That aligns with the proposition that Massachusetts residential leases contain an implied covenant of quiet enjoyment guaranteeing undisturbed use and enjoyment.
Blackett v. Olanoff, 371 Mass. 714 (1977.relevant_excerpt: He ruled that the tenants’ implied warranty of quiet enjoyment was violated by late evening and early morning music and disturbances coming from nearby premises which the landlords leased to others for use as a bar or cocktail lounge (lounge). … Our opinions concerning a constructive eviction by an alleged breach of an implied covenant of quiet enjoyment sometimes have stated that the landlord must perform some act with the intent of depriving the tenant of the enjoyment and occupation of the whole or part of the leased premises.

Blackett v. Olanoff, 371 Mass. at 718\u2.proposition: The covenant of quiet enjoyment is breached where the landlord, by action or omission, causes or permits conditions that substantially interfere with the tenant’s beneficial enjoyment of the premises.

Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth., 417 Mass.raw_text: Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth., 417 Mass. 273, 284–85 (1994)
Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth., 417 Mass.proposition: The covenant of quiet enjoyment is breached where the landlord, by action or omission, causes or permits conditions that substantially interfere with the tenant’s beneficial enjoyment of the premises.
Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth., 417 Mass.case_name: Doe v. New Bedford Housing Authority
Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth., 417 Mass.support_reasoning: The court explicitly defines the covenant of quiet enjoyment as protecting tenants from serious interference with their tenancy caused by acts or omissions of the landlord, and holds that a landlord may breach the covenant by permitting conditions (here, pervasive drug activity in common areas) that substantially interfere with tenants’ use and enjoyment. The opinion emphasizes that liability can arise from what the landlord "failed to do" or "permitted to be done," matching the proposition’s focus on action or omission leading to substantial interference.
Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth., 417 Mass.relevant_excerpt: “The covenant of quiet enjoyment protects a tenant’s right to freedom from serious interference with his tenancy — acts or omissions that impair the character and value of the leasehold. … In analyzing whether there is a breach of the covenant, we examine the landlord’s conduct and not his intentions. … a landlord may not intend to violate a tenant’s right to quiet enjoyment, but may do so nevertheless when the breach is a ‘natural and probable consequence of what the landlord did, what he failed to do, or what he permitted to be done.’ … if the defendant failed to take any action to remove from the area of its control persons engaged in unlawful activity, then the defendant permitted a condition to exist that substantially interfered with the tenancies of the plaintiffs and thus breached the covenant of quiet enjoyment.”

Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth., 417 Mass.raw_text: Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth., 417 Mass. at 284–85
Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth., 417 Mass.proposition: A landlord’s prolonged failure to correct a known and serious defect within a reasonable time after notice constitutes an “indirect” interference with quiet enjoyment within the meaning of G.L. c. 186, § 14.

Simon v. Solomon, 385 Mass. 91, 102\u201.proposition: The landlord’s liability under G.L. c. 186, § 14 may arise from negligent or unreasonable failure to repair serious conditions, including violations of the State Sanitary Code, after notice.
Simon v. Solomon, 385 Mass. 91, 102\u201.support_reasoning: The opinion does interpret G.L. c. 186, § 14 to allow liability without proof of malicious or intentional conduct, extending it at least to reckless conduct. But the court explicitly declines to decide whether negligence or unreasonable failure to repair (after notice or otherwise) suffices for liability under § 14, and instead limits its holding to reckless interference with quiet enjoyment. Thus, the case does not go as far as stating that negligent failure to repair serious, code-violating conditions after notice triggers § 14 liability.
Simon v. Solomon, 385 Mass. 91, 102\u201.relevant_excerpt: “Of course, general statutory objectives do not necessarily justify the broadest reading possible… the Legislature may have contemplated a balance between tenant protection and the legitimate interests of landlords, and therefore may have intended that some degree of fault or foreseeability should be a prerequisite to liability under § 14.… our analysis of the language and history of § 14, however, leads us to conclude that malicious intent is not necessary, and that the statute covers, at the least, reckless conduct such as Gem’s.” (385 Mass. at 101–02).

Simon v. Solomon, 385 Mass. at 102\u2013.proposition: Massachusetts courts have held that serious housing code violations and persistent defects affecting the habitability or substantial use of residential premises can constitute a breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment.

Simon v. Solomon, 385 Mass. at 104\u2013.proposition: The damages alleged by Plaintiff, including but not limited to out‑of‑pocket expenditures for alternative workspaces and loss of rental value and use of the Office Bedroom, are “actual and consequential damages” within the meaning of G.L. c. 186, § 14.

Al\u2011Ziab v. Mourgis, 424 Mass. 847,.proposition: The landlord’s liability under G.L. c. 186, § 14 may arise from negligent or unreasonable failure to repair serious conditions, including violations of the State Sanitary Code, after notice.
Al\u2011Ziab v. Mourgis, 424 Mass. 847,.support_reasoning: The opinion explicitly states that liability under G.L. c. 186, § 14 requires at least negligent conduct and discusses that a landlord’s failure to repair known defects—after notice—has frequently been deemed to violate § 14. It cites prior cases involving failure to repair serious habitability problems (often State Sanitary Code issues) as examples of conduct giving rise to § 14 liability, thereby supporting the proposition that negligent or unreasonable failure to repair serious conditions after notice can create liability under § 14.
Al\u2011Ziab v. Mourgis, 424 Mass. 847,.relevant_excerpt: “Twelve years later, in Cruz Mgt. Co. v. Thomas, supra, we rejected a claim that a violation of G. L. c. 186, § 14, could be imposed only if it were proved that a landlord was reckless in disregarding his tenant’s rights, and we concluded that negligent conduct, conduct involving ‘some degree of fault,’ by a landlord could support the imposition of liability under § 14. Id. at 789. We noted that a landlord’s failure ‘to repair defects of which he has notice in leased premises is an omission which frequently has been deemed to violate § 14.’”}

Al\u2011Ziab v. Mourgis, 424 Mass. at 85.proposition: A landlord’s prolonged failure to correct a known and serious defect within a reasonable time after notice constitutes an “indirect” interference with quiet enjoyment within the meaning of G.L. c. 186, § 14.

Cruz Mgmt. Co. v. Thomas, 417 Mass. 782,.raw_text: Cruz Mgmt. Co. v. Thomas, 417 Mass. 782, 786–88 (1994)
Cruz Mgmt. Co. v. Thomas, 417 Mass. 782,.proposition: Massachusetts courts have held that serious housing code violations and persistent defects affecting the habitability or substantial use of residential premises can constitute a breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment.
Cruz Mgmt. Co. v. Thomas, 417 Mass. 782,.support_reasoning: The court squarely treats serious, code-violating conditions that substantially impair the value and use of a dwelling as a violation of the statutory covenant of quiet enjoyment in G.L. c. 186, § 14. It holds that the landlord’s failure to remedy extensive sanitary, building, and fire code violations—including inadequate heat and hot water and vermin infestation—that “impair substantially the value of the leased premises as a dwelling place” constitutes interference with quiet enjoyment. This directly supports the proposition that serious housing code violations and persistent habitability defects can breach the covenant of quiet enjoyment.
Cruz Mgmt. Co. v. Thomas, 417 Mass. 782,.relevant_excerpt: “Decisions from this court and from the Appeals Court clearly support the imposition of civil liability under § 14 in circumstances like those present in this case. In Ianello v. Court Management Corp., 400 Mass. 321, 323 (1987), it was said that a landlord violates § 14 when his acts or omissions impair the value of the leased premises… Cruz Management had notice of numerous sanitary, building and fire code violations… [It] was wholly foreseeable… that the failure adequately to correct these violations… would impair substantially the value of the leased premises as a dwelling place… On the facts found by the judge a violation of § 14 has been shown.”

Cruz Mgmt. Co. v. Thomas, 417 Mass. at 7.raw_text: Cruz Mgmt. Co. v. Thomas, 417 Mass. at 786–87
Cruz Mgmt. Co. v. Thomas, 417 Mass. at 7.proposition: A landlord’s prolonged failure to correct a known and serious defect within a reasonable time after notice constitutes an “indirect” interference with quiet enjoyment within the meaning of G.L. c. 186, § 14.

Cruz Mgmt. Co. v. Thomas, 417 Mass. at 7.raw_text: Cruz Mgmt. Co. v. Thomas, 417 Mass. at 788
Cruz Mgmt. Co. v. Thomas, 417 Mass. at 7.proposition: Under G.L. c. 186, § 14, Plaintiff is entitled to recover her actual and consequential damages or three months’ rent, whichever is greater, along with costs and reasonable attorney’s fees.
Cruz Mgmt. Co. v. Thomas, 417 Mass. at 7.support_reasoning: The opinion directly quotes G.L. c. 186, § 14’s remedial language, stating that a landlord who interferes with quiet enjoyment “shall … be liable for actual and consequential damages or three month’s rent, whichever is greater, and the costs of the action, including a reasonable attorney’s fee.” This matches the proposition that a plaintiff is entitled to either actual and consequential damages or three months’ rent, whichever is greater, plus costs and reasonable attorney’s fees. The court applies § 14 as written, confirming this measure of recovery.
Cruz Mgmt. Co. v. Thomas, 417 Mass. at 7.relevant_excerpt: General Laws c. 186, § 14 (1992 ed.), provides, in pertinent part, that “any lessor or landlord who directly or indirectly interferes with the quiet enjoyment of any residential premises by the occupant . . . shall ... be liable for actual and consequential damages or three month’s rent, whichever is greater, and the costs of the action, including a reasonable attorney’s fee.”

Wolfberg v. Hunter, 385 Mass. 390, 400\u.proposition: Massachusetts courts have held that serious housing code violations and persistent defects affecting the habitability or substantial use of residential premises can constitute a breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment.
Wolfberg v. Hunter, 385 Mass. 390, 400\u.support_reasoning: The opinion explicitly treats substantial interference with the tenants’ use and enjoyment of the apartment, caused by serious code-related rodent infestation, as a compensable loss of their leasehold rights and confirms liability under the statutory covenant of quiet enjoyment (G.L. c. 186, § 14). The court describes the infestation and related defects as a "substantial interference with the use and enjoyment of the apartment" and upholds a quiet enjoyment award (later disallowed only as duplicative), thereby recognizing that such habitability defects can constitute a breach of quiet enjoyment.
Wolfberg v. Hunter, 385 Mass. 390, 400\u.relevant_excerpt: We believe that the judge erred in thus resolving the issues raised by the plaintiff’s claim for damages. There has been a substantial interference with the use and enjoyment of the apartment to which the tenants were entitled under their lease. This interference with a right guaranteed to them under their lease constitutes a loss of property to the tenants. They had a contractual right to enjoy the use of the apartment free of rodents. The judge found that the tenants withheld rent justifiably.

Berman & Sons, Inc. v. Jefferson, 379 Ma.raw_text: Berman & Sons, Inc. v. Jefferson, 379 Mass. 196, 200–01 (1979)
Berman & Sons, Inc. v. Jefferson, 379 Ma.proposition: The duty to provide and maintain safe and functional electrical service is part of the landlord’s obligation to comply with the State Sanitary Code and to preserve the tenant’s right to habitable and usable premises.
Berman & Sons, Inc. v. Jefferson, 379 Ma.support_reasoning: The opinion clearly ties the landlord’s duty of habitability to compliance with the State Sanitary Code and emphasizes that the landlord must maintain premises in habitable condition, including essential services like heat and hot water. While the case focuses on heat and hot water rather than electrical service specifically, it treats Code-based duties and the implied warranty of habitability as encompassing “facilities vital to the use of the premises for residential purposes,” which logically includes safe, functional electricity. Thus it supports the proposition at a general level, though not by naming electricity expressly.
Berman & Sons, Inc. v. Jefferson, 379 Ma.relevant_excerpt: “For example, the State Sanitary Code… imposed on the landlord a duty to maintain an apartment in habitable condition… The rent-withholding provision embodies a legislative judgment that the tenant’s rental obligation is bound up with the landlord’s obligation to provide habitable premises.” … “In the latter instance, the landlord must comply at least with minimum standards prescribed by the State building and sanitary codes. Whether the scope of the warranty is broader is an open question.”

Darmetko v. Boston Hous. Auth., 378 Mass.raw_text: Darmetko v. Boston Hous. Auth., 378 Mass. 758, 761–62 (1979)
Darmetko v. Boston Hous. Auth., 378 Mass.proposition: Under G.L. c. 186, § 14, Plaintiff is entitled to recover her actual and consequential damages or three months’ rent, whichever is greater, along with costs and reasonable attorney’s fees.
Darmetko v. Boston Hous. Auth., 378 Mass.support_reasoning: The court directly quotes and interprets G.L. c. 186, § 14, explaining that a landlord liable under the statute is responsible for “actual and consequential damages or three months’ rent, whichever is greater, and the costs of the action, including a reasonable attorney’s fee.” The opinion further applies this framework to the plaintiff’s recovery, confirming that the statute provides exactly the remedial scheme stated in the proposition.
Darmetko v. Boston Hous. Auth., 378 Mass.relevant_excerpt: “Section 14 provides that a lessor who commits any act in violation of that section (including interference ‘with the quiet enjoyment of any residential premises’) shall ‘be liable for actual and consequential damages or three months’ rent, whichever is greater, and the costs of the action, including a reasonable attorney’s fee.’ … Section 14 allows a minimum recovery of three months’ rent as an incentive to the pursuit of relief where the actual and consequential damages are slight or are difficult to prove.”

Boston Hous. Auth. v. Hemingway, 363 Mas.raw_text: Boston Hous. Auth. v. Hemingway, 363 Mass. 184 (1973)
Boston Hous. Auth. v. Hemingway, 363 Mas.proposition: Plaintiff also has remedies under related landlord‑tenant doctrines, including the warranty of habitability (see Boston Hous. Auth. v. Hemingway, 363 Mass. 184 (1973)) and G.L. c. 239, § 8A, but in this action she asserts only a claim for breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment under G.L. c. 186, § 14.
Boston Hous. Auth. v. Hemingway, 363 Mas.support_reasoning: This concurring/dissenting opinion in Hemingway explicitly discusses that tenants have statutory remedies under G.L. c. 239, § 8A and that the tenants in this case attempted to invoke § 8A but failed on notice grounds. It also discusses, in depth, the recognition of an implied warranty of habitability as a landlord‑tenant doctrine. While this section is not the majority holding and focuses on tenants as defendants in summary process rather than as plaintiffs, it does support the general proposition that warranty of habitability and § 8A are separate, available landlord‑tenant remedies distinct from a covenant of quiet enjoyment claim under G.L. c. 186, § 14.
Boston Hous. Auth. v. Hemingway, 363 Mas.relevant_excerpt: “The answer of each tenant also ‘claims the protection of … [G. L. c. 239, § 8A …].’ As to each tenant the trial judge found that she had failed to give the written notice required by § 8A… He then properly ruled that § 8A ‘is not available to the defendant as a defense to this proceeding.’ … Having thus failed to qualify for the defence which would otherwise have been available to them under § 8A, the tenants ask this court to give them relief by holding (a) that the landlord impliedly warranted the fitness of their apartments for habitation….”
